ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It works on existing knowledge of general and organic chemistry to move towards environmentally relevant phenomenon such as partitioning, photolysis, and bioaccumulation

I learned about how organic molecules partition into different phases in the environment, both in simplified model systems and in more complex systems. Lots of thermo and equilibrium concepts, as well as how to predict properties of compounds from other data.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I felt that the lectures weren't worth coming to since they felt unorganized, and so I would often watch them after the fact and skip around to my heart's content. On the other hand, Prof. Fortner is a great instructor when one-on-one, and is extremely accommodating, which was an underrated trait until the pandemic happened haha

There is a lot of content to cover but it is well broken up and the book is very easy to follow. The problem sets are challenging, but it feels like this prepares us for the exams. The three exam model feels appropriate for the material also!

Strengths: its a class that really builds on itself  once you figure out the initial thermo stuff, its kind of all repetition from there. Fortner does a great job of pointing that big picture out.
Weaknesses: can rush over some derivations, but theyre not that important.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Fortner was very flexible with deadlines and willing to work with individual students to accommodate our needs.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: if you're an environmental engineering major, this is a great alternative to aquatic chemistry--take this instead

If youre interested! Its definitely a review of thermo, and if youre thinking of working in this kind of remediation/environmental science area, itll do the trick. Fortner is also incredibly nice and accommodating (test corrections!).
Yes, but I would recommend any ENVE course to other students.  Professor Fortner is a great professor to have, and the course material is always interesting and relevant to my future career path.

extras.title:
ENAS 638 01/ENVE 438 01
        Envi Organic Chem/Environmental Organic Chem
